grounding: The origin of modern eukaryotes is one of the key transitions in life's history, and also one of the least understood. Although the fossil record provides the most direct view of this process, interpreting the fossils of early eukaryotes and eukaryote-grade organisms is not straightforward. We present two end-member models for the evolution of modern (i.e., crown) eukaryotes—one in which modern eukaryotes evolved early, and another in which they evolved late—and interpret key fossils within these frameworks, including where they might fit in eukaryote phylogeny and what they may tell us about the evolution of eukaryotic cell biology and ecology. Each model has different implications for understanding the rise of complex life on Earth, including different roles of Earth surface oxygenation, and makes different predictions that future paleontological studies can test.
generated_text: The early fossil record of eukaryotes presents significant challenges for interpretation, particularly in the Precambrian era. This review examines frameworks for understanding eukaryote evolution during the Proterozoic, focusing on the process of eukaryogenesis and its relationship to major environmental changes. We explore the current evidence for early eukaryotic fossils and discuss the potential impact of the Great Oxidation Event on eukaryote diversification. The paper evaluates various hypotheses regarding the timing and mechanisms of eukaryote origin, considering both molecular and fossil data. We also address the limitations of the fossil record and the importance of integrating multiple lines of evidence to reconstruct early eukaryotic evolution. This synthesis provides a comprehensive overview of current perspectives on interpreting the early eukaryotic fossil record and highlights areas for future research.
